message: Hi Michael, thanks so much for taking the time today. I've had a chance to skim your resume and I'd love to start by hearing, in your own words, a bit about your background and what brings you here.

Yeah, sure, thanks for having me. So I've been doing graphic design for a long time, mostly in-house, and I've worked on a lot of different things like print and some digital stuff. I'm kind of at a point where I'm looking for something new and figured this role might be a good fit, or at least a good next step.

That makes sense, and I really appreciate you sharing that. You've clearly been in an in-house environment for quite a while. What kinds of projects do you usually feel most comfortable working on day to day?

I'd say I'm most comfortable with print layouts, like flyers or catalogs, and just kind of making sure things look clean and correct. I can do digital too, though sometimes I need a bit of time to remember best practices since it changes a lot. I usually do better when expectations are clear.
That's totally fair, and honestly pretty relatable. When you're working with others, maybe marketing or sales partners, how do you usually like to communicate and get feedback?

I prefer straightforward feedback, like being told what needs fixing rather than guessing. I try to be easy to work with and responsive, even if I don't always have a big creative opinion right away. I usually wait to see what direction people want before pushing ideas.

I really appreciate that self-awareness. One last thing I'm curious about for now is tools. You've listed quite a few. Are there any you feel especially confident in, or ones you're still growing into?

I'm definitely most confident in Illustrator and InDesign since I've used those forever. Figma I've used, but I wouldn't say I'm advanced with it yet. I can get by and follow existing files, but I sometimes need to look things up or ask questions.
